description: From Middle English complaynen, from Old French complaindre, from Medieval Latin complangere (“to bewail, complain”), from Latin com- (“together”) + plangere (“to strike, beat, as the breast in extreme grief, bewail”); see plain, plaint.

verbs.description: complain (third-person singular simple present complains, present participle complaining, simple past and past participle complained)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To express feelings of pain, dissatisfaction, or resentment.
examples: Joe was always complaining about the noise made by his neighbours.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To make a formal accusation or bring a formal charge.
examples: They've complained about me to the police again.

entries.meaning: To creak or squeak, as a timber or wheel.
